did.unittitle: McCaddon Collection of the Barnum and Bailey Circus
did.abstract: The McCaddon Collection of the Barnum and Bailey Circus consists of correspondence, photographs, scrapbooks, and other material collected by business manager Joseph T. McCaddon prior to the 1907 merger of the circus with Ringling Bros.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: For preservation reasons, original analog and digital media may not be read or played back in the reading room. Users may visually inspect physical media but may not remove it from its enclosure. All analog audiovisual media must be digitized to preservation-quality standards prior to use. Audiovisual digitization requests are processed by an approved third-party vendor. Please note, the transfer time required can be as little as several weeks to as long as several months and there may be financial costs associated with the process. Requests should be directed through the Ask Us Form.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of the working papers of the Barnum and Bailey partnership prior to its merger with Ringling Bros. in 1907. In addition to correspondence, scrapbooks, posters, couriers, parade, costume and wagon designs, music, and memorabilia collected by Joseph T. McCaddon, who was the business manager of the circus at the turn of the century, there are hundreds of photographs documenting the American circus of the 19th and 20th centuries.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research use.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Single copies may be made for research purposes. No further duplication of copies of material in the collection can be made when Princeton University Library does not own the original. Inquiries regarding publishing material from the collection should be directed to Special Collections Public Services staff through the Ask Us! form. The library has no information on the status of literary rights in the collection and researchers are responsible for determining any questions of copyright.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The collection was a gift to the Library by the McCaddon family in 1941. Additions were purchased at auction in July 1978.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of specific item; Date (if known); McCaddon Collection of the Barnum and Bailey Circus, Box and Folder Number; Special Collections, Princeton University Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Melanie Papasian, Princeton Class of 2003 and Rachel Jordan in 2002 and 2004 . Finding aid written by Melanie Papasian, Princeton Class of 2003 and Rachel Jordan in 2002 and 2004.
The existence of harmful language was noted in collection- and series-level descriptive notes by Amy C. Vo and Phoebe Nobles in 2022 as an initial step for reparative description-related work.
In 2022, restrictions on glass-plate negatives were lifted as part of a restrictions review project.

scopecontent.head: Content Warning
scopecontent.p: The McCaddon Collection of the Barnum and Bailey Circus contains harmful and offensive descriptions of people that includes racist, colonialist, ableist, and otherwise dehumanizing language. Some of the description is original to the donor and/or the creator, and in these instances of creator- and donor-supplied titles, description may be retained to convey contextual/historical information of the materials. However, the collection is a candidate for ongoing reparative description work that can address cases in which a librarian or archivist may have supplied harmful descriptive language. We hope that researchers will engage in a dialogue with staff about issues in the collection and changes that could help.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: The glass-plate negatives require special handling in the reading room.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Joseph T. McCaddon was born on January 31, 1859, in Beverly, Washington County, Ohio. McCaddon began his career with the circus as manager of the Adam Forepaugh Circus. Later, as James A. Bailey's brother-in-law and business manager of the Barnum and Bailey Circus, he represented Bailey in many business matters, including correspondence with William F. Cody ("Buffalo Bill") regarding the acquisition of his Wild West Show.

chronitem.event: John Robinson Circus formed
Adam Forepaugh Circus formed
P. T. Barnum begins "P.T. Barnum's Museum, Menagerie, & Circus" in Brooklyn, N.Y.
James A. Bailey buys interest in Hemmings and Cooper's Circus from James E. Cooper, changes name to Cooper and Bailey Circus.
Sells Bros. Circus formed

Bailey, along with Cooper and James L. Hutchinson, purchases show owned by Seth B. Howes, forming Howes' Great London Circus and Sanger's Royal British Menagerie and Cooper & Bailey's International Allied Shows
Cooper retires; Bailey and Hutchinson form partnership with Barnum, creating the Barnum and London Circus.
Buffalo Bill's Wild West founded
The Ringling Brothers establish their circus.
Bailey sells his interest in the circus to Cooper and W. W. Cole.
Barnum and Bailey begin sole partnership, forming the "Barnum and Bailey Circus."
Bailey and Cooper buy Adam Forepaugh Circus.
Barnum dies; Bailey assumes full ownership of Barnum and Bailey Circus.
Bailey buys a controlling interest in Buffalo Bill's Wild West.
Bailey joins with W. W. Cole and two of the Sells Brothers; Sells Bros. Circus becomes Adam Forepaugh and Sells Bros. Circus
5-year Barnum and Bailey European Tour. Ringling Bros. Circus becomes dominant American Circus.
Ringling Bros. begin to lease John Robinson Circus.
Bailey acquires full ownership of Adam Forepaugh and Sells Bros. Circus, sells half interest in it to the Ringling Bros.
Bailey dies; Ringling Brothers buy remaining share of Forepaugh-Sells Circus from Bailey's widow.
Ringling Brothers purchase "Barnum and Bailey Circus" (shows remain separate).
"Ringling Brothers Circus" combined with "Barnum and Bailey Circus" to create "Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus"
Ringling Brothers purchase American Circus (which consisted of Sells-Floto, Al G. Barnes, Sparks, Hagenbeck-Wallace, and John Robinson Circuses).
Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus gives last big top performance.
Irvin Feld purchases "Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus" and transforms it into an indoor show.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of photographs of exotica, performers, animal acts, "freaks," and equipment used by the circus.

scopecontent.head: Content Warning
scopecontent.p: Many of the photographs in this series contain dehumanizing and harmful descriptions using racist, colonialist, and ableist language. In the majority of cases, the descriptions of people have been transcribed from the photographs themselves. Some of the photographs have been stamped with titles (likely by the original photographic studio); other titles are handwritten. In cases where photographs have no title, descriptions derive from a typewritten inventory of the collection that may have been provided by the donor, or may have been created by an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of 25 scrapbooks on James A. Bailey, Barnum and Bailey vs. Sells Bros. Opposition, and European Tour, as well as others.

scopecontent.head: Content Warning
scopecontent.p: Some of the scrapbooks contain photographic prints which have been described with racist, colonialist, ableist, and dehumanizing language. In cases where scrapbook photographs are not captioned, descriptions in the finding aid derive from a typewritten inventory of the collection that may have been provided by the donor, or may have been created by an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of deeds, contracts, correspondence, minute books, music, maps, handbills, artwork, and costume design, as well as other materials.

scopecontent.head: Content Warning
scopecontent.p: This series contains harmful and offensive descriptions of people that may include racist, colonialist, ableist, and dehumanizing language. Some of the description is original to the donor and/or the creator, and in these instances of creator- and donor-supplied titles, description may be retained to convey contextual/historical information of the materials. Otherwise, descriptions derive from a typewritten inventory of the collection that may have been provided by the donor, or may have been created by an archivist.

did.unittitle: Personal of both J.A. Bailey and J.T. McCaddon, 1884-1936, including personal memorandum book of Bailey, 1876-1877
1890: Transactions re. McCaddon's move from Minn. Dime Shows to Forepaugh w/Cooper 1899 consolidation of B&B. 1894, misc
1900: Transactions re. International exchange rate and Bailey's bank transfers. 1901 death and will related material of Dr. Stanton, veterinary surgeon for B&B, McCaddon executor. Misc
1902: Money transfers, Bailey. 1903: Teamsters' demand of B&B

1904: McCaddon's resignation as director of B&B. Bailey-McCaddon correspondence, purchase of Forepaugh-Sells. McCaddon-Bailey re. McCaddon's purchase of old B&B Paraphernalia Bailey-McCaddon and Bailey et. Al. re. McCaddon use of Hippodrome. 1905: death of Mayme McCaddon. Misc
1906: Death of Bailey and complications, letters re. McCaddon's installation as Chairman of the Board. B&B correspondence re interest in Forepaugh-Sells Bros. Shows

1907: Cody & Bailey - profit and loss account, correspondence. 1908 more Cody & Bailey. Unused certificate of incorporation of Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show. Correspondence re. law suits. J.T. McCaddon chairman and executor. 1909: B&B Ltd. liquidates

1931: Re. cruelty to circus animals. J.T. McCaddon with Spectator, London. 1935: Seely-McCaddon re. "The Mighty Barnum." 1937: McCaddon, Major G.W. Lillie re. N.Y. World's Fair exhibit. Also letter to Kilpatrick re. use of Madison Square Garden Bowl for above exhibit

1907: Contract between Barnum & Bailey Circus and Ringling Bros. 1908: Letter to J.T. McCaddon from Holmes & Rogers Lawyers. 1908: Letter to A.A. Stewart from Otto Ringling. 1908: Letter to A.A. Stewart from Charles Rogers. 1906: Minutes of Meeting of the Board of Directors of Barnum and Bailey, Ltd.
1905-1906: Partnership Agreement-J.A. Bailey and Ringling Bros.; Sale of Estate of J.A. Bailey to Ringling Bros. Of the Adam Forepaugh and Sells Bros. Shows
1871-1872. Agreement, J.E. Cooper with Bailey and Middleton
Partnership agreement: J.E. Cooper, J.A. Bailey, Robert Hood
Agreements: 1874: Lease on Louisville Exposition Building. 1877: Charter S.S. "Claudia Hamilton". 1878: Charter S.S. "Golden Sea"
